title: Tech Show and Tell – Our Team’s Coolest Gear!
description: Check out what you can fix with iFixit at  and use code CELEBRATE for free standard shipping on orders over $65. Code active starting November 21st!  Our staff often get to be hands-on with the newest tech before most people have a chance to order it but what about at home? What sort of tech do they splurge on for passion projects and hobbies? Its time for another round of show and tell!  Discuss on the forum:   Buy a Hario V60 Buono Kettle:  Buy a Bonavita Digital Kettle:  Buy a Hario Pour Over Set:  Buy a 1Zpresso JX-Pro Grinder:  Buy a Timemore Coffee Scale:  Purchases made through some store links may provide some compensation to Linus Media Group.   GET MERCH:   SUPPORT US ON FLOATPLANE:   AFFILIATES, SPONSORS & REFERRALS:   PODCAST GEAR:    FOLLOW US  ---------------------------------------------------   Twitter:  Facebook:  Instagram:  TikTok:  Twitch:   MUSIC CREDIT --------------------------------------------------- Intro: Laszlo - Supernova Video Link:  iTunes Download Link:  Artist Link:   Outro: Approaching Nirvana - Sugar High Video Link:  Listen on Spotify:  Artist Link:   Intro animation by MBarek Abdelwassaa  Monitor And Keyboard by vadimmihalkevich / CC BY 4.0   Mechanical RGB Keyboard by BigBrotherECE / CC BY 4.0  Mouse Gamer free Model By Oscar Creativo / CC BY 4.0   CHAPTERS --------------------------------------------------- 0:00 Intro 0:43 Old and rare... and bad games! 3:51 IBM made really cool PCs 6:50 Zunes for your tunes 10:11 Coffee tools are tech! 14:42 Let's use the tools 19:19 Do good tools mean good taste? 21:41 Outro

This is a very, very good quality hand grinder and it's pretty expensive as far as they go. And the reason for that is the build quality. When you look into coffee grinders, you can get them for 20, 30 bucks and they can go all the way up to thousands upon thousands of dollars. The reason that it is good quality is because of the tolerances involved in its machining. It's also a fully metal burr set. What happens when you grind coffee is it has a burr here that grinds against this burr, which is just a set of metal pieces that try to crush the coffee as it's being fed through by gravity or by the rotational movement of your hands. This is important because this shaft is very, very carefully machined. When you have a grinder that's potentially cheaper, it's gonna have a lot more wobble, and so the grounds are gonna be different sizes when they come out. Coffee is just in general a chemical process. The closer that you can make a variable to a specific point, the more accuracy you can have with the end result because there's a lot of variables along the process that create the outcome of coffee. The reason that I use a hand grinder, part of it is cost. This is just affordable for somebody who doesn't need to put out a lot of ground coffee like a coffee shop or somebody that's selling it. What we're gonna do is take 30 grams of coffee and 500 grams of water, which is approximately a 20% burr ratio. I've also got a coffee scale here. The reason that the coffee scale is important is because this has very, very specific accuracy. It's, I believe, good down to 0.1 grams, which is pretty tight for kitchen scales, and it's also very fast. It's almost instant to come to the specific point of weight. That's important for when I'm actually brewing the coffee. I can see how much water that I put in at a specific point in time.
